questions.text: The sonographic appearance of the endometrium during the menstrual cycle correlates with the phasic changes in its histologic anatomy. Which phase of the cycle is depicted with the classic trilaminar appearance as shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Proliferative

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a transvaginal scan showing a tri-laminar (triple layer) endometrium seen in the proliferative phase.
  • • This is a transvaginal scan showing a tri-laminar (triple layer) endometrium seen in the proliferative phase.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: In the menstrual phase, the endometrium is very thin. Option B: In the secretory phase, the endometrium appears homogenous. Option D: In the peri-ovulatory period, the endometrium will be very thick and trimlaminar just prior to ovulation and gradually become homeogenous once ovulation has happened so there isn't 1 defined appearance in the peri-ovulatory period
  • • Option A: In the menstrual phase, the endometrium is very thin.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: In the secretory phase, the endometrium appears homogenous.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: In the peri-ovulatory period, the endometrium will be very thick and trimlaminar just prior to ovulation and gradually become homeogenous once ovulation has happened so there isn't 1 defined appearance in the peri-ovulatory period
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Different TVS images at different phases of the menstrual cycle
  • ➤ Secretory Endometrium: As seen above, it is a homogenous endometrium
  • ➤ Secretory Endometrium: As seen above, it is a homogenous endometrium
  • ➤ Proliferative Endometrium: As seen above it is a tri-laminar endometrium
  • ➤ Proliferative Endometrium: As seen above it is a tri-laminar endometrium
  • ➤ Menstrual phase: As seen above it is a very thin endometrium

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding development of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis in the female fetus and neonate?

options.label: A
options.text: The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth.

options.label: B
options.text: By 5 months’ gestation, 6 to 7 million oocytes have been created from accelerated germ cell division.

options.label: C
options.text: At birth, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) concentrations rise and remain high during the first 3 months of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Neonatal breast budding, minor uterine bleeding, and transient ovarian cysts may occur as a normal response to initially high gonadotropin levels.

questions.correct_answer: A. The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A carefully orchestrated cascade of events unfolds in the neuroendocrine system and regulates development of the female reproductive system. In utero, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons develop in the olfactory placode. These neurons migrate through the forebrain to the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus by 11 weeks’ gestation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), a decapeptide, is influenced by higher cortical centers and is released from these neurons in a pulsatile fashion into the pituitary portal plexus. As a result, by mid gestation, the GnRH “pulse generator” stimulates secretion of gonadotropins, that is, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), from the anterior pituitary. In turn, the pulsatile release of gonadotropins stimulates ovarian synthesis and release of gonadal steroid hormones. Concurrently, accelerated germ cell division and follicular development begins, resulting in the creation of 6 to 7 million oocytes by 5 months’ gestation. By late gestation, gonadal steroids exert negative feedback on secretion of both hypothalamic GnRH and pituitary gonadotropins. During this time, oocyte number decreases through a process of gene related apoptosis to reach a level of 1 to 2 million by birth At birth, FSH and LH concentrations rise abruptly in response to the fall in placental estrogen levels and are highest in the first 3 months of life. This transient rise in gonadotropin levels is followed by an increase in gonadal steroid concentrations, which is thought to explain instances of neonatal breast budding, minor bleeding from endometrial shedding, short-lived ovarian cysts, and transient white vaginal mucous discharge. Following these initial months, gonadotropin levels gradually decline to reach prepubertal levels by age 1 to 2 years. The childhood years are thus characterized by low plasma levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol. Estradiol levels typically measure < 10 pg/mL, and LH values are < 0.3 mIU/mL.
  • • A carefully orchestrated cascade of events unfolds in the neuroendocrine system and regulates development of the female reproductive system.
  • • In utero, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons develop in the olfactory placode.
  • • These neurons migrate through the forebrain to the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus by 11 weeks’ gestation.
  • • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), a decapeptide, is influenced by higher cortical centers and is released from these neurons in a pulsatile fashion into the pituitary portal plexus.
  • • As a result, by mid gestation, the GnRH “pulse generator” stimulates secretion of gonadotropins, that is, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), from the anterior pituitary.
  • • In turn, the pulsatile release of gonadotropins stimulates ovarian synthesis and release of gonadal steroid hormones.
  • • Concurrently, accelerated germ cell division and follicular development begins, resulting in the creation of 6 to 7 million oocytes by 5 months’ gestation.
  • • By late gestation, gonadal steroids exert negative feedback on secretion of both hypothalamic GnRH and pituitary gonadotropins.
  • • During this time, oocyte number decreases through a process of gene related apoptosis to reach a level of 1 to 2 million by birth
  • • At birth, FSH and LH concentrations rise abruptly in response to the fall in placental estrogen levels and are highest in the first 3 months of life.
  • • This transient rise in gonadotropin levels is followed by an increase in gonadal steroid concentrations, which is thought to explain instances of neonatal breast budding, minor bleeding from endometrial shedding, short-lived ovarian cysts, and transient white vaginal mucous discharge.
  • • Following these initial months, gonadotropin levels gradually decline to reach prepubertal levels by age 1 to 2 years.
  • • The childhood years are thus characterized by low plasma levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol.
  • • Estradiol levels typically measure < 10 pg/mL, and LH values are < 0.3 mIU/mL.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A carefully orchestrated cascade of events unfolds in the neuroendocrine system and regulates development of the female reproductive system. In utero, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons develop in the olfactory placode. These neurons migrate through the forebrain to the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus by 11 weeks’ gestation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), a decapeptide, is influenced by higher cortical centers and is released from these neurons in a pulsatile fashion into the pituitary portal plexus. As a result, by mid gestation, the GnRH “pulse generator” stimulates secretion of gonadotropins, that is, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), from the anterior pituitary. In turn, the pulsatile release of gonadotropins stimulates ovarian synthesis and release of gonadal steroid hormones. Concurrently, accelerated germ cell division and follicular development begins, resulting in the creation of 6 to 7 million oocytes by 5 months’ gestation. By late gestation, gonadal steroids exert negative feedback on secretion of both hypothalamic GnRH and pituitary gonadotropins. During this time, oocyte number decreases through a process of gene related apoptosis to reach a level of 1 to 2 million by birth At birth, FSH and LH concentrations rise abruptly in response to the fall in placental estrogen levels and are highest in the first 3 months of life. This transient rise in gonadotropin levels is followed by an increase in gonadal steroid concentrations, which is thought to explain instances of neonatal breast budding, minor bleeding from endometrial shedding, short-lived ovarian cysts, and transient white vaginal mucous discharge. Following these initial months, gonadotropin levels gradually decline to reach prepubertal levels by age 1 to 2 years. The childhood years are thus characterized by low plasma levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol. Estradiol levels typically measure < 10 pg/mL, and LH values are < 0.3 mIU/mL.

questions.text: Precocious puberty is defined as initial pubertal changes occurring prior to what age?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For girls, precocious puberty has historically been defined as breast or pubic hair development in those younger than 8 years. Causes of precocious puberty

questions.text: During the past several decades, the ages at which girls experience thelarche and menarche have shown which of the following trends?

options.label: D
options.text: No clear trend has been observed

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Earlier trends of puberty are now being experienced In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height, termed a growth spurt, during a 3-year span from ages 10.5 to 13.5 years. Higher BMI correlates with earlier pubertal development. The mean age o menarche in white girls is 12.7 years and 6 months earlier, or 12.1, in black girls
  • • Earlier trends of puberty are now being experienced
  • • In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years
  • • Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height, termed a growth spurt, during a 3-year span from ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.
  • • Higher BMI correlates with earlier pubertal development.
  • • The mean age o menarche in white girls is 12.7 years and 6 months earlier, or 12.1, in black girls

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Earlier trends of puberty are now being experienced In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years

questions.text: Sustained gonadotropin secretion requires which of the following patterns of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GnRH pulsatile secretion causes increase in gonadotropin release Higher pulse frequency preferentially stimulates LH, whereas lower frequency favors FSH secretion
  • • GnRH pulsatile secretion causes increase in gonadotropin release

questions.text: A 33-year-old female is being followed for a 5-mm prolactin-producing pituitary adenoma, which is well controlled on bromocriptine 0.5 mg orally daily. She presents with a positive pregnancy test result. What is the next best step?

options.label: C
options.text: Check a prolactin level and if it is elevated, continue bromocriptine therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and base decisions on these findings

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The pituitary gland enlarges during pregnancy, primarily due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the lactotrophs in response to elevated serum estrogen levels. Although the tumor can enlarge during pregnancy, the risk of clinically significant growth is small. Significant expansion may lead to headaches or compression of the optic chiasm and blindness, visual field testing is considered in every trimester or women with macroadenomas. Dopamine agonist therapy has been associated with an increased risk of spontaneous abortion, preterm deliveries, and recommendations are that dopamine agonist therapy be discontinued during pregnancy when possible.
  • • The pituitary gland enlarges during pregnancy, primarily due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the lactotrophs in response to elevated serum estrogen levels.
  • • Although the tumor can enlarge during pregnancy, the risk of clinically significant growth is small.
  • • Significant expansion may lead to headaches or compression of the optic chiasm and blindness, visual field testing is considered in every trimester or women with macroadenomas.
  • • Dopamine agonist therapy has been associated with an increased risk of spontaneous abortion, preterm deliveries, and recommendations are that dopamine agonist therapy be discontinued during pregnancy when possible.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page 387, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 387, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: At what stage of the female life is the highest number of oocytes found in the ovary?
questions.correct_answer: D. In utero at 5 months’ gestation
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The maximum number of oocytes are at 20 weeks of fetal life (6 milion) These keep decreasing and at birth, a girl is born with about 1 million At puberty, there are 400,000 oocytes By menopause there are around 400 oocytes

  • • These keep decreasing and at birth, a girl is born with about 1 million
  • • At puberty, there are 400,000 oocytes
  • • By menopause there are around 400 oocytes

questions.text: Meiosis I of the oocytes is completed at which of the following times?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Primary oogonia enter meiosis in utero (in fetal life) to become primary oocytes. These oocytes are arrested in development at prophase during the first meiotic division. Meiotic progression resumes each month in a cohort follicle. Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge. Meiosis II begins, and the process is arrested, this time in the second meiotic metaphase. Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized
  • • Primary oogonia enter meiosis in utero (in fetal life) to become primary oocytes.
  • • These oocytes are arrested in development at prophase during the first meiotic division.
  • • Meiotic progression resumes each month in a cohort follicle.
  • • Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge.
  • • Meiosis II begins, and the process is arrested, this time in the second meiotic metaphase.
  • • Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: 376, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: 376, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following zona pellucida proteins is responsible for zona hardening after sperm penetration?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The human zona pellucida contains at least 4 proteins, named ZP1, ZP2, ZP3and ZP4 Successful fertilization depends on the ability of sperm to penetrate the extracellular matrix of the zona pellucida that surrounds Enzymes released from the acrosome induce alterations in ZP2 that result in hardening of the coat and this prevents fertilization of the oocyte by more than one sperm
  • • The human zona pellucida contains at least 4 proteins, named ZP1, ZP2, ZP3and ZP4
  • • Successful fertilization depends on the ability of sperm to penetrate the extracellular matrix of the zona pellucida that surrounds
  • • Enzymes released from the acrosome induce alterations in ZP2 that result in hardening of the coat and this prevents fertilization of the oocyte by more than one sperm
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: ZP1: Cross links ZP2 and 3 Option C: ZP3: Allows species specific sperm binding Option D: ZP4: the role of ZP4 is not yet clearly understood
  • • Option A: ZP1: Cross links ZP2 and 3
  • • Option C: ZP3: Allows species specific sperm binding
  • • Option D: ZP4: the role of ZP4 is not yet clearly understood

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Successful fertilization depends on the ability of sperm to penetrate the extracellular matrix of the zona pellucida that surrounds
  • ➤ Enzymes released from the acrosome induce alterations in ZP2 that result in hardening of the coat and this prevents fertilization of the oocyte by more than one sperm

questions.text: In the image below, which line corresponds to luteinizing hormone level changes during the menstrual cycle?
questions.explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This chart of the hormonal changes in the menstrual cycle is very important Remember that ovulation is preceded by the LH surge which is in turn preceded by a rise in estrogen Also remamber that following ovulation, progesterone increases and this peaks at Day 21.

questions.text: Images A and B, respectively, correspond to which of the following menstrual cycle phases?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Proliferative phase: straight to slightly coiled, tubular glands are lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with scattered mitoses. Early secretory phase: coiled glands with a slightly widened diameter are lined by simple columnar epithelium with clear subnuclear vacuoles. Stroma is variably edematous in the secretory phase. Late secretory phase: serrated, dilated glands with intraluminal secretion are lined by short columnar cells. Menstrual phase: fragmented endometrium with condensed stroma and glands with secretory vacuoles are seen in a background of blood.
  • • Proliferative phase: straight to slightly coiled, tubular glands are lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with scattered mitoses.
  • • Early secretory phase: coiled glands with a slightly widened diameter are lined by simple columnar epithelium with clear subnuclear vacuoles. Stroma is variably edematous in the secretory phase.
  • • Late secretory phase: serrated, dilated glands with intraluminal secretion are lined by short columnar cells.
  • • Menstrual phase: fragmented endometrium with condensed stroma and glands with secretory vacuoles are seen in a background of blood.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page 383, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 383, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition

questions.text: In this sample of cervical mucus, the effect of which of the following hormones can be seen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This smear is showing a ferning pattern which is seen due to estradiol The cervical glands secrete mucus that is normally thick and impervious to sperm and ascending infections. High estrogen levels at midcycle change the quality of this mucus. It becomes thin and stretchy and has an increased sodium chloride concentration causing the Ferning pattern on a dried smear as shown in the image
  • • This smear is showing a ferning pattern which is seen due to estradiol
  • • This smear is showing a ferning pattern which is seen due to estradiol
  • • The cervical glands secrete mucus that is normally thick and impervious to sperm and ascending infections.
  • • High estrogen levels at midcycle change the quality of this mucus.
  • • It becomes thin and stretchy and has an increased sodium chloride concentration causing the Ferning pattern on a dried smear as shown in the image

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estradiol causes a ferning pattern on cervical mucus smear as shown below
  • ➤ Estradiol causes a ferning pattern on cervical mucus smear as shown below
  • ➤ Estradiol causes a ferning pattern on cervical mucus smear as shown below

questions.text: A 7-year girl is brought to the OPD. Her mother has noted vaginal bleeding for 2 days which is small in quantity staining her undergarments. She shows no signs of pubertal development. The cause of the bleeding is not apparent during physical examination, and the decision is made to proceed with examination under anesthesia and saline vaginoscopy. What is the most likely finding?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Neonates may present with vaginal bleeding during the first week of life due to the withdrawal of maternal hormones at birth and this b leeding typically resolves after a few days. Prepubertal bleeding in a child, however, merits careful evaluation Most instances of vaginal bleeding in these girls are due to local causes and can be elucidated with a simple history and physical examination. Occasionally, an examination under anesthesia with saline vaginoscopy is required to rule out a foreign body in the upper vagina
  • • Neonates may present with vaginal bleeding during the first week of life due to the withdrawal of maternal hormones at birth and this b leeding typically resolves after a few days.
  • • Prepubertal bleeding in a child, however, merits careful evaluation
  • • Most instances of vaginal bleeding in these girls are due to local causes and can be elucidated with a simple history and physical examination.
  • • Occasionally, an examination under anesthesia with saline vaginoscopy is required to rule out a foreign body in the upper vagina
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B: Atrophic vaginitis: This is a common cause of bleeding in the post-menopausal age group Option C: Endocervical polyp: This is a common cause of inter-mentrual bleeding in the reproductive age group and less common in children Option D: Sarcoma botryoides: This is a malignant tumor that arises from the immature skeletal muscle cells (rhabdomyoblasts) of hollow organs like the vagina or bladder or biliary tract. It most commonly affects children < 4y and classically presents as a mass resembling a bunch of grapes.
  • • Option B: Atrophic vaginitis: This is a common cause of bleeding in the post-menopausal age group
  • • Option B: Atrophic vaginitis:
  • • Option C: Endocervical polyp: This is a common cause of inter-mentrual bleeding in the reproductive age group and less common in children
  • • Option C: Endocervical polyp:
  • • Option D: Sarcoma botryoides: This is a malignant tumor that arises from the immature skeletal muscle cells (rhabdomyoblasts) of hollow organs like the vagina or bladder or biliary tract. It most commonly affects children < 4y and classically presents as a mass resembling a bunch of grapes.
  • • Option D: Sarcoma botryoides:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 354, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 354, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 5-year girl develops precocious puberty. Gonadotropin levels are low, even following gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) infusion stimulation testing. Estrogen levels are elevated. Which of the following could NOT be a cause of her disorder?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a case of peripheral (or GnRH independent) precocious puberty Features of peripheral precocious puberty: Elevated estrogen levels LH and FSH are low GnRH stimulation shows no elevation in serum LH level. Causes of peripheral precocious puberty include all mentioned except pituitary tumors Pituitary tumors cause central (GnRH dependent) precocius puberty
  • • This is a case of peripheral (or GnRH independent) precocious puberty
  • • Features of peripheral precocious puberty: Elevated estrogen levels LH and FSH are low GnRH stimulation shows no elevation in serum LH level.
  • • Elevated estrogen levels LH and FSH are low GnRH stimulation shows no elevation in serum LH level.
  • • Elevated estrogen levels
  • • LH and FSH are low
  • • GnRH stimulation shows no elevation in serum LH level.
  • • Causes of peripheral precocious puberty include all mentioned except pituitary tumors
  • • Pituitary tumors cause central (GnRH dependent) precocius puberty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page 355, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 355, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
